is an ENSCO Senior Engineer focusing on high-precision
RF ranging and timing. He was the Sensors Technical
Lead for the national semifinalist Team Case for the 2007
DARPA Urban Challenge and won a Best Student Paper
award at the 2008 IEEE Sensors Conference. Mr.
Farnsworth holds the B.S. in Electrical Engineering
summa cum laude from Case Western Reserve University
and anticipates graduating with the M.S. in Electrical
Engineering from Case in May 2010.
Dr. David W.A. Taylor

is
ENSCO's Director of Technology Development, where
he leads the company's R&D programs developing
sensors and systems for national security applications.
Dr. Taylor holds three U.S. patents and is an expert in
GPS-denied navigation technologies, particularly as
applied to military and intelligence applications. Dr.
Taylor holds the B.S. in Physics from Rhodes College and
the Ph.D. in Geophysics from Virginia Tech.
front.div:
ABSTRACT
A round-trip, time-of-flight, high-precision, ranging radio
operating in the 915 MHz ISM band is presented. A
custom digital baseband processor is implemented on a
Xilinx Virtex-4 FPGA and interfaced with COTS RF
hardware. Processing gain enabled by direct-sequence
spread-spectrum (DSSS) signaling directly improves the
ranging accuracy. The system is designed with free-
running baseband clocks that do not require fine
synchronization.
Prototype brassboard system
measurement accuracies of 7 cm (1-Ïƒ) have been obtained
during testing in an open field.
